website_summaries.verdict: Backed by a credible expert, this field guide provides significant value for those conducting research on edible wild plants.
pros: Book is handy in size, making it easy to bring on all foraging expeditions
Book is both accurate and easy to understand, even for beginners
Information is specific in nature, which is what other field guides sometimes lack
cons: Features drawings rather than actual images

customer_reviews.title: Not as good as others like it...
customer_reviews.text: I ordered this book as well as Edible Wild Plants by Thomas S. Elias & Peter A. Dykeman. This book relies on drawings and has very few color photos whereas the book by Elias and Dykeman is all color photos and a much easier to use and higher quality guide.
customer_reviews.author: Sarah

customer_reviews.title: Not Good. Drawings, not actual photos. :(
customer_reviews.text: When trying to identify items of nature to be edible, nonedible, to poisonous, I would imagine actual images be used instead of 1 dimentional drawings. Book is useless for quick referencing guide, and confusing even with a more in depth glance to identify a plant.
customer_reviews.author: KOOCH

customer_reviews.title: The black and white drawings are pretty much useless to identify plants
customer_reviews.text: Unless you already have knowledge in the field, The black and white drawings are pretty much useless to identify plants. The book has very few color photos. I can see how easy it would be to make an identity mistake by using this book. The descriptions can be vague and often leaves out useful information. Also the preparation of plants are pretty bad as well. I think this author is more interested in scattering information across multiple books in an effort to sell more, than he is in delivering complete and useful information.
customer_reviews.author: Christopher Litton

customer_reviews.title: A Bit of A Disappointment
customer_reviews.text: I bought this field guide hoping for something chocked with good photos that can really help you identify various plants and herbs out in the wild. The written information is there but many of the pictures are simply black and white drawings - something that in my opinion doesn't help a lot in the field. There is a section in the middle of the book that has colored photographs but then you have to look at the photo and try to find the matching description elsewhere in the book. Not the best lay out for field study. I would prefer to have colored photos right along side each plant description for easy identification.
customer_reviews.author: SavvvyShopper

customer_reviews.title: Color photos of ALL PLANTS needed!
customer_reviews.text: The information in this book is in itself useful, but the pictures mostly are B&W drawings ( there are color pictures, though only a small percentage compared to all the plants covered in this book.), and in some descriptions there are multiple types of a single type of plant and individual photos of each type would be much more useful instead of just B&W drawings.
customer_reviews.author: Christopher

customer_reviews.title: This book can help you get there but you'll have to do the walking
customer_reviews.text: Excellent. Peterson's has a well-earned reputation and maintains it with this field guide. While there are a lot of color photos, the preponderance of graphics are sketches. Strongly recommend anyone interested in learning about foraging for wild edibles to start slow, be sure and build your skills through time. The book can help you get there but you'll have to do the walking.
customer_reviews.author: Jim Sr.

customer_reviews.title: and this book makes it easy to identify wild plants which are safe to nibble ...
customer_reviews.text: When this came in the mail, my elderly mother-in-law, who is an avid reader, commented," I bet you're the only one on earth who has bought that book!" LOL I am an outdoor enthusiast, and this book makes it easy to identify wild plants which are safe to nibble on, as well as those "look- alikes" that could turn out to be deadly. If you have an itch to go foraging for wild foods, and don't want a REAL itch, this book is a good one to have in hand!
customer_reviews.author: Suzette G. Martin

customer_reviews.title: You ate WHAT?
customer_reviews.text: This is an excellent field guide for collecting edibles and avoiding things that could make your day(s) miserable! Nothing worse than throwing something in the stew pot that does NOT belong in there! KNOW before you throw.... Great pictures to help you identify what you should and should NOT pick, especially where there are look-alikes that could cause problems. Handy size, ready for your next "field" excercise!
customer_reviews.author: ICUL8R

customer_reviews.title: Does not address garlic mustard!
customer_reviews.text: Considering this is one of the preeminent plant books I am disappointed that it fails to highlight edible invasives such as garlic mustard that are ruining the ecosystem. Garlic mustard here in Kentucky is outcrowding the natives and the curved root, self pollination, and root exudates it produces to kill other plants and butterfly larvae that feed on it make it worse. I hope the author and others realize the obligation to inform the public of the destruction to the ecosystem being caused by this plant. Moreover the color picture section is relatively small.
customer_reviews.author: Will

customer_reviews.title: Okay
customer_reviews.text: It contains a lot of entries, which is good for vastly expanding your knowledge, but I do not feel confident of positive identification of poisonous vs. edible plants after viewing illustrations of lookalikes. Trust me, you will be confused, unless you are already an expert. Good to know, but not handy for positive identification in the field. Buy more than one book on identification. It's better to know 1/4 of the plants very well.
customer_reviews.author: S P

customer_reviews.title: Small enough for a hiking pack
customer_reviews.text: Ive only read through the introduction so far, but i like how the narrative is written. It speaks from a 1st person perspective on living off the land. This book is a continuation of something i believe they say their father had written first? This is his take on what he learned from his roots basically. The illustrations are great and it even offers colored photos in a section of the book showing what you can eat
customer_reviews.author: Demetrius

customer_reviews.title: The best source for plant identification
customer_reviews.text: I'm a little obsessed at identifying plants, and so I don't go anywhere without this book. Especially hiking or walking. I consider it the "bible" of this subject. True there are a lot of pictures crammed into it, and they are mostly line drawings. But it's comprehensive. I first identify plants using this book, THEN go to other sources (including online) for more information on that plant, including how to prepare/eat it/ or use it for medicinal purposes.
customer_reviews.author: Pamela Olivetree

customer_reviews.title: Not a true field version of a truly great guide.
customer_reviews.text: Very disappointed, not a true Peterson's Field Guide! $20 and it's not coated. I have a couple Peterson's Field Guides, they are full color and very durable. The reason the pages are coated in a real Peterson's Field Guide is because they are meant to be used OUTSIDE. This cheaply made version would be ruined in a light rain. This book should cost $7 or less.
customer_reviews.author: Amazon Customer

customer_reviews.title: My GO TO Guide Just What I Need!
customer_reviews.text: This is an outstanding field guide! This book is my go to guide in the field. FULL of info and easy to understand plain simple language. Easy to understand symbols to state if its edible or not etc. It says Easter and Central North America but many of these plants are found all over America. It also gives pictures of the plant, in all stages and the 'fruit' in each stage etc. Just awesome!
customer_reviews.author: Southpaw Bushcraft

customer_reviews.title: My standards are pretty high for plant identification books because I want to ...
customer_reviews.text: This is a helpful book but I didn't give it five stars because some of the pictures are too close or don't show enough detail to be sure on a identification. My standards are pretty high for plant identification books because I want to be sure before I eat something. That being said for an identification book to get 4 stars from me it has to be pretty solid. These Peterson guides seem to for the most part do a nice job.
customer_reviews.author: Thrift Schooling

customer_reviews.title: Great little book
customer_reviews.text: Great little book, so many edible plants I did not know about. Tells about some edible weeds that I have growing in my yard. Should be handy to bring while traveling in the eastern and Central US, in case you get lost and need a food source.
customer_reviews.author: Catrina Rom

customer_reviews.title: Very nice
customer_reviews.text: I found this book to be very accurate, as well as entertaining. I enjoyed looking up plants that I have seen around my house and in the woods. The descriptions are detailed, and the glossary is really easy to use. I especially appreciate the colored picture section. Too bad the whole book couldn't be in color. I expect that would cost a fair bit more, but I would definitely buy it!
customer_reviews.author: berry44

customer_reviews.title: not what I expected
customer_reviews.text: I am not a fan of this book at all! It contains a lot of info, but the photos are almost like black and white sketches, which makes it difficult in verifying the plants i am trying to identify. I would not buy this again.
customer_reviews.author: Lina

customer_reviews.title: Excellent pocket-size, reputable guide for immediate use and further study.
customer_reviews.text: Excellent introduction and explanation of terms, organisation, methods, use, and sources. Organization is logical and easy to follow. Recommended reading and additional resources are extensive, making this a great starter for further study. Plant descriptions are a little cluttered, but that's an expected (and acceptable) compromise for the portable size of print. Overall an excellent starter guide for the region with basic terminology and imagery. I would prefer more actual photographs rather than illustrations, but given the original time of print this is an outstanding resource. The author clearly put a lot of time and effort into research and the academic-style introduction and inclusion of additional sources is very impressive. Great work!
customer_reviews.author: carode

customer_reviews.title: Skip this guide and go with Natures Garden instead
customer_reviews.text: This book is an illustrated guide with drawn pictures of plants both edible and inedible. Im not going to trust my safety to a depiction of a plant. Why this publisher decided to use drawings in nearly this entire book is beyond me. Natures Garden by Samuel Thayer is available on Amazon as well and this book does a far superior job at explaining this topic. Samuels passion for foraging comes thrrough a lot clearer that this text book. Its a few dollars more but well worth it. Skip this guide and go right to the better source. I own both and prefer Natures Garden far more.
customer_reviews.author: Bobul

customer_reviews.title: Decent starter book
customer_reviews.text: Decent for a starter book. Hardly any photographs but rather drawings. And only basic info to allow the reader to understand edibleness. Could have left out mushrooms as one shouldn't trust "any" mushroom to a book. Not to mention mushrooms are not plants, but fungi and a different subject altogether separate from plants . They could have used this extra space for better and up to date photographs.
customer_reviews.author: Randall W

customer_reviews.title: Love it so much imma buy another one!
customer_reviews.text: Absolute best resource on wild edible plants. Although there are limited color photos, the drawings are excellent and make it easy to cross reference with plants you come across. I also like how they have different environments and the wild edible plants that typically grow in them as well as what grows during which season.
customer_reviews.author: Galanda

customer_reviews.title: A valuable training aid
customer_reviews.text: An excellent resource but not a panacea. As others have indicated, no book is a complete substitute for experience. Also, drawings do give a level of detail and scale not always evident in color photographs, so some of it comes down to how a person processes information.
customer_reviews.author: Don D Cline

customer_reviews.title: Good specific and detailed information
customer_reviews.text: The book covers many plants, no complaints. Good specific and detailed information. Drawings. 90% of the pictures are drawings. I am not mentally equipped to use drawings and written descriptions and identify specific plants comfortably. I need photos. The more the better.
customer_reviews.author: Amazon Customer

customer_reviews.title: Prepping or camping, this is the book to have
customer_reviews.text: Very useful book. I am a Survival Specialist and I LOVE these books. Every time I move or travel to a new location I buy the book that is associated with the area I am in. The pictures and descriptions are great and very informative. I also enjoy how the book described all the different uses, from medicinal to using the plant as a food source. A preppers best friend
customer_reviews.author: The Romans

customer_reviews.title: Backpacking and backwoods living
customer_reviews.text: Both this with Peterson Field Guide to Medicinal Plants. Both books are great and FULL of info. I bought it for my bug out bag. I don't see taking these in a back pack for bugging out. But back packing in the back country would be neat to use to identify plants. Word of CAUTION. Don't take this book and head back in the woods and start eating mushrooms and plant. You are asking for trouble. This kind of skill takes a lot of time and knowledge. Many many years. But very helpful book
customer_reviews.author: jitou812

customer_reviews.title: Great information and format.
customer_reviews.text: Small enough to carry in your hip pocket or pack while hiking. Very logical format for guiding you from a plant of fruit you see to identification and info on edibility and ways to prepare if appropriate. Also, has a special section on the few plants on the east coast that are seriously toxic. This is a great feature to ease your mind while you are learning
customer_reviews.author: David C Johnson

customer_reviews.title: First-rate Field Guide
customer_reviews.text: Absolutely fabulous book. Covers nearly all the major edible wild plants of the Eastern U.S. Very few color photographs...this is disappointing but the artist illustrations are so accurate and the written descriptions so good that I can still give this book five stars. A perfect manual for wilderness hiking or browsing around the woods behind your home.
customer_reviews.author: The Hellbender

customer_reviews.title: Love it
customer_reviews.text: Love this book. Fits easily into my bag, so I can take it anywhere with me, without taking up too much room. Very informative. Very easy to use. It's already helped me identify several different plants while on my walks.
customer_reviews.author: Chell

customer_reviews.title: Lacking In Comparison
customer_reviews.text: I purchased this book because of how much I enjoyed the medicinal plants book by the same company. This book is very difficult to navigate and lacks the same quality that the medicinal plants book has. Although still packed with fantastic content, because everything in this book is drawn rather than a color photo, and doesn’t contain one for every plant to help with identification, it will probably stay on my bookshelf rather than come with me on adventures.
customer_reviews.author: JW

customer_reviews.title: Peterson's Field Guide to Eastern and Central Edible Wild Plants
customer_reviews.text: Excellent edible plants book ! Lots of crucial information on looking for edibles when your out in the back country ! This book goes with me in addition to the National Audubon mushroom field guide when am out looking for wild food. My favorite edibles guide!
customer_reviews.author: Jeff

customer_reviews.title: Worth having in your camping/cooking kit
customer_reviews.text: it was copyrighted in 1977, not sure if it's been updated since but man is it useful. Looking for a little variety in your daily diet? Get it. Planning on a bug out/ survival event? Get it. Going camping via tent and hiking? Get it. Very entertaining and quite useful to have on hand.
customer_reviews.author: My Opinion

customer_reviews.title: I am disappointed for a few reasons
customer_reviews.text: I am disappointed for a few reasons. most of the pictures are drawings and not the actual photo of the plant, which would have served as a means of identification. If they were more color photos as we have become a visual people. A lot of time was invested in the research and this is a good thing.
customer_reviews.author: Xanthone New York

customer_reviews.title: Great visual
customer_reviews.text: I'm teaching my boyscouts about local plants, this is a great tool with black and white pictures of every plant listed. It also tells you how to beat prepair/eat each one or if it's poison.
customer_reviews.author: Amy E. Klick

customer_reviews.title: Great backpacking size.
customer_reviews.text: I have been utilizing this book quite a bit. At first I disliked the black and white sketches of plants.... And then I tried to backpack with another full color book that weighed 5 pounds. I quickly began to love the smaller size and better detail you get with illustrations than actual pictures. I have easily identified over 35 plants on my last hike, and it has opened my eyes to the abundance of natural food obtainable in the wild. I give it 5 stars.
customer_reviews.author: Vicki

customer_reviews.title: A little lacking for a beginner
customer_reviews.text: I spent a bit of time perusing this book, and came away only a little more informed. That's mostly because I didn't feel confident about applying much of what I read. I haven't gone out "hunting" yet, but I think I'm going to need a companion book to reference when I'm not sure about something. I'm glad I bought it, but I'm going to have to find something to supplement this. It is well-organized though, and the written descriptions are fair. The drawings are good, but I feel better with color photos and a section on the "dont's" would have helped.
customer_reviews.author: schericane

customer_reviews.title: Good book. Covers a large area.
customer_reviews.text: Book is pretty good for basic identification. This covers a large portion of the us. While traveling in the woods, it’s best to have a pocket guide for a quick reference. This book is good reads if you are targeting specific plants.
customer_reviews.author: Icanbitemyownear

customer_reviews.title: Wow!  Edible Plants are all around us!
customer_reviews.text: Edible plants are all around us, we just have to know where to look. This book helps tremendously! We enjoyed perusing the book with its many accurate drawings and color plates. The index really helps as well. This is one book you really need to purchase for your backpack; emergency situations happen, people get lost and everyone needs to know what plants are safe and which are not. Great book!
customer_reviews.author: Paul

customer_reviews.title: Having read Peterson's bird guides pretty carefully, I can safely say that I like ...
customer_reviews.text: First off, let me say that I'm a bit of a field-guide nut, snob, and collector. Having read Peterson's bird guides pretty carefully, I can safely say that I like this edible plant guide even more. The images are crisp and I've found the descriptions to be spot-on. If you're looking for a mushroom guide, I'd suggest a dedicated book that is just about mushrooms. This is not to say that mushrooms are not covered in this book; I just think some of the other mushroom-only guides are worth having if you're into edible fungi.
customer_reviews.author: Spencer in Seattle

customer_reviews.title: Good Resource
customer_reviews.text: This is a good book for anyone interested in that sort of thing. I bought it because I thought it would be a god send to have in the event that our modern world is flipped upside down but I'm learning there are some real opportunities just browsing around the back yard. I think we've become so accustomed to modern conveniences that we don't realize that the remedy to our ailments may be closer than you think.
customer_reviews.author: Munch

customer_reviews.title: Very Informative
customer_reviews.text: I like everything about this book. The illustrations are great and the wording is easy to read and understand. I think the only thing that could make this better is if with every book there was a downloadable version that I could have. It would make it a lot more portable to have on my tablet along with all of the other books!
customer_reviews.author: Harold

customer_reviews.title: Look down, eat up!
customer_reviews.text: If you live in a city you better know how to eat your way up the highway. Should the trucks stop rolling we city dwellers are about two hours from living in a food free environment...unless you know what to eat in Central Park. If it works for the huge body mass of elephants and giraffes then vegetation should at least give us a shot at short term survival.
customer_reviews.author: Erica Martell

customer_reviews.title: Great purchase, what we were hoping for
customer_reviews.text: Great book! Organized great. Only wish there was a bit more detail in the plant drawings or photos of the plants.
customer_reviews.author: Jeremy Trost

customer_reviews.title: Great for survival situation or your bug out bag if ...
customer_reviews.text: Great for survival situation or your bug out bag if your like me and you don't know a lot about plants it would be a shame not to have it so you could supplement your food sources when you're in the wild safely
customer_reviews.author: Maria C

customer_reviews.title: A most useful little book.
customer_reviews.text: Very informative. It's a wonder to me that Mr. Peterson was able to cram so much useful information into one knapsack-sized book. I wish there was a companion volume that expanded much more and contained many more illustrations. It would necessarily be a big, unwieldy, book, but I think it would make a wonderful reference in any serious outdoorsman's library.
customer_reviews.author: David B. Hinton

customer_reviews.title: Plant Recognition. Best book out there.
customer_reviews.text: The book is inclusive of plant material. Gave my book to neighbor and bought a new copy for me.
customer_reviews.author: broclelady

customer_reviews.title: wonderful book
customer_reviews.text: so comprehensive - just wish it was a little bigger or maybe just bigger print for old people
customer_reviews.author: Debbie

customer_reviews.title: Good to get started
customer_reviews.text: Good description of habit and habitat but pictures need improvement.
customer_reviews.author: Forrest J.

customer_reviews.title: Beautiful
customer_reviews.text: Had this field guide on my wish list for quite some time. Finally bought it for myself for Christmas. I wasn't disappointed.
customer_reviews.author: Toro Tatum

customer_reviews.title: This book reveals some great information. The only problem I have with it ...
customer_reviews.text: This book reveals some great information. The only problem I have with it is some plants are hard to identify given the drawings or picture of each plant. A nice color photograph would be nice for each. I personally find myself having to go to other books or online to help me identify each plant.
customer_reviews.author: Amazon Customer

customer_reviews.title: Good book
customer_reviews.text: easy to read and understand and definitely better than eating a poisonous plant!
customer_reviews.author: Robin H

customer_reviews.title: Very Happy with this Purchase!
customer_reviews.text: Easy and wonderful guide! Super happy we chose to make this purchase. Looking forward to exploring it more and in greater depth!
customer_reviews.author: Shelby

customer_reviews.title: It has a lot of good information, but the pictures are lacking
customer_reviews.text: It has a lot of good information, but the pictures are lacking. Most of the plants have just black and white sketches, not enough color photos. This was bad, because some edible plants greatly resemble poisonous ones, so it was hard to tell them apart with the poor quality pictures.
customer_reviews.author: Amazon Customer

customer_reviews.title: Excellent reference, but be cautious.
customer_reviews.text: Very useful reference to wild edible plants. A note of caution a lot of the pictures of plants in the book are hand drawn. So if you're unfamiliar with plant identification I would exercise caution as there are a lot of "look alike" plants that could ruin your day. Otherwise excellent resource for the outdoors enthusiast.
customer_reviews.author: C. Bricker

customer_reviews.title: Great pictures and details
customer_reviews.text: A very good book I am so glad I bought this. Nice details of plants.
customer_reviews.author: P.J.

customer_reviews.title: Someone needs to do a book just to identify plants
customer_reviews.text: You need to already be familure with the plants in this book for it to be much use to you. I think they could have done much better with the discriptions and drawings of the plant. I have spent a lot of time in the forests in Missouri and they were few plants that were recogniazable to me. I know all about POLK and so do most Missourian born people. I know the plants like poison oak and ivy. Not much help.
customer_reviews.author: mainaird

customer_reviews.title: Why to eat the plants is not included
customer_reviews.text: It is a very thorough book, but the one thing missing, that I think would be the most important part about each edible plant, is the edible quality of each plant. Like the medicinal, or non medicinal reasons to eat it, is it a diuretic or not, things like that.
customer_reviews.author: Becky

customer_reviews.title: Its good. I bought it because it has drawings of ...
customer_reviews.text: Its good. I bought it because it has drawings of representative plants rather than a phone of one example of a species. A bit easier to ID plants, I felt. Got it to know what I am looking at as I walk around the deer woods. Lots of interesting stuff to possibly eat: pecans, walnuts, raspberries, mint, etc here in W. Illinois. Bought the Eastern Trees book too.
customer_reviews.author: Randizzle

customer_reviews.title: Three Stars
customer_reviews.text: This book is ok...illustrations could be more detailed and descriptions could be better
customer_reviews.author: Jyunks

customer_reviews.title: Three Stars
customer_reviews.text: A decent descriptive tome, but it would be improved with photos instead of drawings.
customer_reviews.author: Tango

customer_reviews.title: I recommend if you're into survival knowledge.
customer_reviews.text: Bought this on a whim because I want to learn more woodcraft. It's so great. The illustrations are excellent and I can identify so many more things in the forest now. A sturdy book with solid bindings. Still hasn't deteriorated despite being dropped in the snow several times
customer_reviews.author: Alyssa Rogalla

customer_reviews.title: Good info
customer_reviews.text: Repetative wording. Takes to long to get to the point.
customer_reviews.author: Kim Fields

customer_reviews.title: Not so great, but I wanted to love it.
customer_reviews.text: I wanted to love this book because it has tons of information. But it's organization is very confusing. There are only a couple pages of color pictures. The rest are black and white sketches. Also, print is tiny! Read the other reviews and you'll understand how confusing the structure of this book is.
customer_reviews.author: JP

customer_reviews.title: Fantastic Resource
customer_reviews.text: So glad I had this today. One of my daughter's classmates ate an unidentified berry from a vine that grew through the playground fence. No one knew what it was. I live close to the school and was able to get this book and find that she ate a Virginia Creeper berry. While poisonous, it should only cause a tummy ache since she only ate one. Knowing allowed the mom to have an educated discussion with poison control and give her piece of mind about the situation. I was able to quickly identify the plant by the very detailed description in the book. Will be buying another to give to her school director.
customer_reviews.author: CML

customer_reviews.title: AMAZING find
customer_reviews.text: Amazing facts and information on how to obtain eternal health and LIFE
customer_reviews.author: Yochanna Yah

customer_reviews.title: A lot of information
customer_reviews.text: I thought this book was good because it had a lot of information. I went through the first time and just looked at different leaf structure, roots and just generally looked at the pictures because I was slightly over whelmed. But later I was able to go back and read about the different plants. Some of which I was familiar with others I had never seen before. I need one for Western North America and Alaska!
customer_reviews.author: Travis L.

customer_reviews.title: Good Book
customer_reviews.text: Good and practical information. I used it on a weekend camping trip and was able to identify a few plants--including poison ivy.
customer_reviews.author: Tammara Buckey

customer_reviews.title: A great thing to take camping/hiking with you.
customer_reviews.text: I really enjoy this book. Even though the illustrations aren't in color, they show you the parts of the plant that are important. I keep this book in my backpack that I take everywhere with me, to work, school, on hikes, camping, etc. It's small enough to fit in a little pocket and not take up too much space. I haven't ever had the need to depend on edible wild plants, but I'm prepared with this book.
customer_reviews.author: kpcrescentTop Contributor: Fountain Pens

customer_reviews.title: Invaluble aid....
customer_reviews.text: This book has proven to be an excellent source for identifying common plants in my yard. I had no idea so many of the "weeds" in my yard were actually edible! The only drawback to this book is that it mainly contains drawings instead of color photos, so it becomes highly important to read the details of each plant throughly before choosing to eat it. I've gone so far as to collect a salad of wild greens and it was very tasty! Simply add in a bit of lettuce, cucumber, tomato, and whatever else you like, then sprinkle on a little dressing and you have a nutritious and delicious salad! :D
customer_reviews.author: Denise P.

customer_reviews.title: Great
customer_reviews.text: Great story, great detail. Extra like how to cook stuff. What's dangerous and what's good how to easily learn the plants. Etc.
customer_reviews.author: Roy G Quinones

customer_reviews.title: Intuitive, thorough guide for the curious survivalist and gastronaut
customer_reviews.text: This handy field guide is replete with sketches, photos, and detailed identifying information that makes it easy for the layperson to spot wild edibles. It does a great job of highlighting subtle differences between edible and not-so-edible plants. The preparation tips, caveats ("You can eat it, but you probably don't want to unless you're starving to death"), and interesting factoids make this an entertaining book even if you're not interested in eating what you identify.
customer_reviews.author: R. Johnson

customer_reviews.title: Bought this for my dad who has become very interested ...
customer_reviews.text: Bought this for my dad who has become very interested in foraging. My mom called me one day stating "great, now he tries every plant in the backyard." Needless to say, he loves it ! Haha
customer_reviews.author: CHAMOMILERN

customer_reviews.title: Amazing!
customer_reviews.text: I love it! Basic sketches AND some of the most vivid color pictures you've ever seen on your life! So far seems to have all the right information with no filler or nonsense. My delivery arrived on time as well.
customer_reviews.author: Mr. H

customer_reviews.title: Five Stars
customer_reviews.text: I live in a wooded acerage area. This book will help to discover what grows here.
customer_reviews.author: Denise M. Sullivan

customer_reviews.title: Good to have if the internet is down.
customer_reviews.text: Very interesting book. I like to learn off grid survival skills so I keep this in a bug out bag.
customer_reviews.author: Melissa L. Reeder

customer_reviews.title: Hugely Informative....
customer_reviews.text: I just received this hugely informative reference book and can't wait to take it with me on one of my outdoor peregrinations. It's typical "Peterson," i.e., loaded with all the essential information you'll want when rendering a decision on a potentially edible plant.
customer_reviews.author: Wallerish

customer_reviews.title: A priceless resource
customer_reviews.text: A must have for survivalists and campers alike. Has both illustrations and color pics for easy identification of edible and poisonous plantlife.
customer_reviews.author: Amazon Customer

customer_reviews.title: great information and the photos are very important in this ...
customer_reviews.text: great information and the photos are very important in this case. also has nice quick check lists in the back
customer_reviews.author: Maggie

customer_reviews.title: Needed for any outdoor enthusiast's library
customer_reviews.text: This is one of the essential books for any outdoor mountain/forest enthusiast. Just below a well illustrated book on wildflowers. Since my lake is very polluted with too many reeds, I am handing out recipes to all my neighbors.
customer_reviews.author: littljeane

customer_reviews.title: Great Books!
customer_reviews.text: Loads of knowledge in this book...now if I can just buy the one for my region! Not their fault, I wasn't paying attention. Would seriously recommend for anyone that spends any amount of time in the great outdoors.
customer_reviews.author: CC

customer_reviews.title: Knowing what not to eat is just as important
customer_reviews.text: Book is broken down into sections for ease of understanding and pictures are great
customer_reviews.author: Ken Manspeaker

customer_reviews.title: It's solid
customer_reviews.text: Good drawings and descriptions but with modern technology it would be really easy to get some color photos, especially for those dangerous look alikes.
customer_reviews.author: HS Chem Teacher

customer_reviews.title: Great notations of how they can be used and which ...
customer_reviews.text: Detailed description of plants. Great notations of how they can be used and which ones are poison.
customer_reviews.author: Amazon Customer

customer_reviews.title: I was disappointed on the lack of better pictures
customer_reviews.text: I was disappointed on the lack of better pictures. Specifically color pictures. the majority are black and white drawings. there are some color plates in the center of the book. I would not use this as my main guide only as a reference to help confirm what other books and pictures are also confirming.
customer_reviews.author: Sohlenlede

customer_reviews.title: Good reference manual
customer_reviews.text: Peterson does its usual good job, but the book should have color drawings and four season pictures of the plants. Same problem for almost all of these type of books. Otherwise good information and a good book to learn from. There are not enough pictures for the total number of plants in the book.
customer_reviews.author: C Gates

customer_reviews.title: Highly recommend!!
customer_reviews.text: Very informative little guide. I love that it has pictures.
customer_reviews.author: Ariel

customer_reviews.title: Love this!
customer_reviews.text: I bought mine used and it's in great shape, I love this book! Super useful
customer_reviews.author: Amazon Customer

customer_reviews.title: Good knowledge for when the politics make the world tank ...
customer_reviews.text: Good knowledge for when the politics make the world tank and the grocery stores become overrun with thieves and vandals and raiding and looting are the way of survival. I will hunt my own food and not from a can. A good book to own if you want to escape the idiocy we have created and named society.
customer_reviews.author: Al McGrover

customer_reviews.title: 4 TO 5 STARS
customer_reviews.text: GOOD INFORMATION BUT A SMALL PAPERBACK BOOK. DIDN'T KNOW THE BOOK WOULD BE THIS SMALL. EASY TO CARRY IN A BACKPACK, HOWEVER !!!
customer_reviews.author: KNOWSTRUTH

customer_reviews.title: Godd info and great size
customer_reviews.text: These small books are so handy for hiking and exploring. They are small enough to carry with you but are filled with great pictures and lots of information. The only problem I have had is with the binding. A few pages have come loose and I had to tape them.
customer_reviews.author: Sheila Stallcup

customer_reviews.title: I have always been into survival stuff and this is ...
customer_reviews.text: I have always been into survival stuff and this is helpful with that but it has also been coming in handy on the Green Witch path
customer_reviews.author: Amazon Customer

customer_reviews.title: Fairly good book.
customer_reviews.text: The book has lots of good information. I would say the lack of colorful pictures of each species would be better. Other than that i really like the book.
customer_reviews.author: Jeff T

customer_reviews.title: great information
customer_reviews.text: My only problem with this book is that the writer assumes you already know your plants, if i did, i wouldnt have purchased the book I would know what was edible. And it is scattered, It would have been really nice if they put all edible plants in their zones even if it were repeated. they did separate the zones but not enough plants in each zone.
customer_reviews.author: Katy S. Wilson

customer_reviews.title: has been very useful on hikes time and time again
customer_reviews.text: You can't beat a Peterson guide. This book, as a reference digest, has been very useful on hikes time and time again.
customer_reviews.author: Jillian Wolf

customer_reviews.title: Very few photos. Almost exclusively b&w drawings. Also ...
customer_reviews.text: Very few photos. Almost exclusively b&w drawings. Also has a cheaper binding than my other Peterson guide. This one is akin to a cheap paperback binding.
customer_reviews.author: RTL

customer_reviews.title: Five Stars
customer_reviews.text: very handy to have in the field while learning about local wild edibles.
customer_reviews.author: britny

customer_reviews.title: Decent
customer_reviews.text: Read it almost all the way through. Wish it had more color pictures, especially of the stuff that would kill you if eatn
customer_reviews.author: JR

customer_reviews.title: Awesome, had this book about a week
customer_reviews.text: Awesome, had this book about a week, love it already. Tons of plants in it, already identified quite a few with it, and tried a few that I didn't know were edible. Well organized, love the way this book is set up. Would buy again 10/10
customer_reviews.author: nathan

customer_reviews.title: Perfect.
customer_reviews.text: Get this book if you are doing any type of survival prep or training. It is great, and the photos are a huge bonus. It explains the positives and where to find the plant species and what to look for. I also bought the companion book Medicinal Wild Plants. I was very pleased with these books and take them out whenever I am hiking now.
customer_reviews.author: Lee

customer_reviews.title: Three Stars
customer_reviews.text: Needed better information and close up pictures about what the plant looks like.
customer_reviews.author: da
